componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question comes from the line of Dara Mohsenian of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you discuss demand elasticity so far from the higher pricing you've taken? It looks like it's been pretty muted with the solid organic sales growth. So I'm just wondering where demand elasticities are coming in versus your expectations, particularly i
componenttext: Can you discuss demand elasticity so far from the higher pricing you've taken? It looks like it's been pretty muted with the solid organic sales growth. So I'm just wondering where demand elasticities are coming in versus your expectations, particularly in Latin America and Russia, given some of the macro difficulties there. And then as we look going forward as FX pressure continues to worsen, do you plan to take incremental pricing internationally because I imagine at some point you don't want to push too far from a consumer standpoint? And then last, just a detail question, the pricing number was very strong in Latin American Foods and I suspect in the Latin piece of PAB. How much of that was driven by Venezuela versus other geographies?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dara, overall, I tell you demand elasticity in these times, when you've got high inflation and you've got transactional FX hitting countries which require us to take pricing, the challenge is to balance volume and revenue. And what we do in most cases is
componenttext: Dara, overall, I tell you demand elasticity in these times, when you've got high inflation and you've got transactional FX hitting countries which require us to take pricing, the challenge is to balance volume and revenue. And what we do in most cases is that we try to push through as much of the inflation as we can, raw material inflation as we can through pricing. In many cases, we cannot cover all of it. But we try to price through about 75% of the inflation. And then we manage very judiciously the revenue output and make sure that our volume decline is not significant. For example, let me take Russia. In Russia, we have pushed through a lot of pricing, and we've married it up with a lot of productivity also. And so our results in Russia, and our business is doing very well. The real issue is yes, there's some volume dropoff, but I think in these times, we have to judiciously manage revenue and volume, and then as the economies recover, go back to volume growth. If we don't push pricing through now, it would be very hard to push it all through later on to cover all of these costs. So at every point in time in each of these countries, that's what we do. And in terms of ongoing FX, spot rates are slightly better than consensus. We have to watch and see how this thing evolves. But in every country again, every country is not moving exactly the same way. But country-by-country, as FX moves, especially transactional FX, impacts country performance, we do take pricing at least to cover 75% of that. And the rest of it, we try to cover through productivity. And as far as Venezuela is concerned, I mean, the footnotes in the Qs will indicate exactly the impact of Venezuela. And I think it'll speak for itself.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, just to comment, a lot of companies reporting this morning. You put out a pretty efficient press release that was easy to read. I guess, my question is and somewhat related to Dara's question is if we kind of look out over the balance of the year,
componenttext: First, just to comment, a lot of companies reporting this morning. You put out a pretty efficient press release that was easy to read. I guess, my question is and somewhat related to Dara's question is if we kind of look out over the balance of the year, there's certainly some volatility still, I guess, we could expect in Russia and potentially Venezuela. And so if you could just talk to -- you've maintained your currency-neutral guidance and you also maintained your free cash flow guidance in the context still of having that type of volatility. So could you talk just about what some of the factors that you're watching for that might drive some variances to those forecasts? And even specifically on free cash flow, what other actions can you take if you still have -- you're still compromised on foreign exchange moving against you?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to let Hugh talk about cash flow. But I'd just make an overall comment. Russia, the business is doing very well, Bryan. Retail, dairy products, juice products, basic snacks, the business is doing very well. We have an excellent team in Russ
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to let Hugh talk about cash flow. But I'd just make an overall comment. Russia, the business is doing very well, Bryan. Retail, dairy products, juice products, basic snacks, the business is doing very well. We have an excellent team in Russia, great productivity programs, putting the pricing through in very judicious ways, doing very good revenue management. I'm very proud of the Russia team. And so we are managing through this volatility very well. And Venezuela, the business is doing exceedingly well in Venezuela. The issue is the currency. So let's hear Hugh now talk about what he's doing on the free cash flow to make sure that as a company, we deliver on our commitments on free cash flow. Go ahead, Hugh.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, happy to. Really a couple of things. Number one, we do continue to localize even more aggressively than we have in the past. And obviously, that helps us manage from a currency perspective, which helps us manage from a free cash flow perspective. Num
componenttext: Yes, happy to. Really a couple of things. Number one, we do continue to localize even more aggressively than we have in the past. And obviously, that helps us manage from a currency perspective, which helps us manage from a free cash flow perspective. Number two, we are managing CapEx very tightly. You've seen us over the last few years come down from the mid-5s in terms of CapEx as a percent of revenue to we've been operating in the low 4s. And then third, we've managed working capital from what had previously been about 21 days down to about 3 days. In all candor, I still think we have more opportunity in that regard, particularly on inventory. And we're going to continue to work that as quickly as we can in order to mitigate if there are further downsides. Right now, we're giving you market consensus, it's our best guess. So definitionally, that's a 50-50 as to which way it's going to go. But I do think we can continue to do more from an inventory perspective in order to continue to cover if we have further downsides from an FX perspective.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our new operating model is also allowing us to come up with more productivity ideas across the company. So that's what we are working as a company against [ph].
componenttext: And our new operating model is also allowing us to come up with more productivity ideas across the company. So that's what we are working as a company against [ph].

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Schmitz of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Schmitz of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, I know it sounds like a random question, but are you guys going to close down Muller? I saw a big impairment charge in the quarter. So is that just to sort of write it down to the fair value now? And is that still going to be an initiative you guys a
componenttext: Hey, I know it sounds like a random question, but are you guys going to close down Muller? I saw a big impairment charge in the quarter. So is that just to sort of write it down to the fair value now? And is that still going to be an initiative you guys are going to work through?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not closing down Muller. The business is still running and doing well. But I think it just didn't meet our expectations, and we have to go through some retooling. But no, that business is alive and kicking.
componenttext: We're not closing down Muller. The business is still running and doing well. But I think it just didn't meet our expectations, and we have to go through some retooling. But no, that business is alive and kicking.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, my question is more on the PAB margin performance in the quarter, Hugh. I guess, it's the first quarter in the last few quarters that margin did decline year-over-year. I know in the press release, you did cite lapping some of the onetime item
componenttext: So I guess, my question is more on the PAB margin performance in the quarter, Hugh. I guess, it's the first quarter in the last few quarters that margin did decline year-over-year. I know in the press release, you did cite lapping some of the onetime items. But can you just walk through the margin performance in PAB? And how much was timing versus just really some of the spending that you're doing to drive the business to grow from a top line perspective?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, a couple of elements there, Judy. First of all, the pricing environment is quite healthy. We felt terrific about pricing in the quarter and we expect that to continue going forward. Two other drivers, obviously, advertising and marketing was up a bit
componenttext: Yes, a couple of elements there, Judy. First of all, the pricing environment is quite healthy. We felt terrific about pricing in the quarter and we expect that to continue going forward. Two other drivers, obviously, advertising and marketing was up a bit for the quarter, and that's timing of the curve. That's one of the elements. The other elements are some of the timing on spending with our Latin American bottlers that drove that number. But we certainly expect PAB margins to continue to grow over time as they have been.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Caroline Levy of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Caroline Levy of CLSA.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one quick one, why did you leave the charge in the Quaker operating income? Is there a good reason for that? And then it would be great if you could just tell us what it's like on the ground in Russia and Brazil right now, possibly even Mexico, becau
componenttext: Just one quick one, why did you leave the charge in the Quaker operating income? Is there a good reason for that? And then it would be great if you could just tell us what it's like on the ground in Russia and Brazil right now, possibly even Mexico, because there's a sense that things are deteriorating in Brazil, for example. So it'd just be great to hear from you.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: We left the charge in the Quaker operating income because it's managed as Quaker Muller...
componenttext: We left the charge in the Quaker operating income because it's managed as Quaker Muller...

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's the accounting, it's part of the line of business.
componenttext: Yes, that's the accounting, it's part of the line of business.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the ground in Russia, as Hugh just mentioned, we've been localizing costs. And we have a very, very good team that's doing all the right things in terms of productivity, taking pricing, adjusting the product line to make sure it is suited for a Russian
componenttext: On the ground in Russia, as Hugh just mentioned, we've been localizing costs. And we have a very, very good team that's doing all the right things in terms of productivity, taking pricing, adjusting the product line to make sure it is suited for a Russian consumer that's shopping differently now. And so I'd say that on the ground in Russia, the business is doing well. And I think it's also giving an opportunity for all companies operating in Russia to look and see how to tighten their belts and work with each other to lower each other's costs. So except for the overall macro geopolitical issues in Russia, on the ground, the business in Russia looks okay. In terms of Mexico again, we've operated in Mexico for decades and we've operated through massive volatility. At this point, we're not seeing that kind of volatility at all in Mexico. We have pockets of security issues, but overall, Mexico is just fine. Brazil did see a slowdown coming off the real weakening, and then on top of that, the draft issues happening in Brazil. Yes, we did see some turmoil -- I'm sorry, in Brazil. And our business is still holding, Caroline. But I'd say of the 3 countries that you mentioned, probably in the last quarter, Brazil is where we saw some on-the-ground action that we are watching very carefully at this point.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ali Dibadj of Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ali Dibadj of Bernstein.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, I had 2 questions. One is just to zoom in on costs a little bit, please. I want to understand a little bit more of what's driving some of the commodity inflation being higher for the year, why for FL and PAB, you had an operating cost inflation.
componenttext: Actually, I had 2 questions. One is just to zoom in on costs a little bit, please. I want to understand a little bit more of what's driving some of the commodity inflation being higher for the year, why for FL and PAB, you had an operating cost inflation. Is that wages? And then importantly also, just as you continue to cut the $1 billion of costs, you have a few more years of that, but what happens after that? So that's the cost question. And the other one is I know it's early days, but you're seeing Coca-Cola refranchise more and more of its U.S. bottling operations. Are you seeing anything that shows a change in pattern of their activity in the marketplace?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm going to answer 2 parts, then I'm going to turn it to Hugh on commodity inflation. As I mentioned in my script, Ali, we talked about the $1 billion per year for the next 5 years. But when we announced the $1 billion a year for the next 5 years, we sta
componenttext: I'm going to answer 2 parts, then I'm going to turn it to Hugh on commodity inflation. As I mentioned in my script, Ali, we talked about the $1 billion per year for the next 5 years. But when we announced the $1 billion a year for the next 5 years, we started working on the next round of ideas to think about even more productivity opportunities. And we'll come back and talk to you about it when we're ready to talk about it. But believe me, once we changed the operating model of the company to really look across the company as opposed to allowing each country and region to just operate independently, there are more opportunities for efficiency. So that's what we're working on. And in terms of the Coke refranchising its bottling operations, let's not forget why we bought back the bottling assets. We bought it back because we wanted to improve efficiency in the system. And most importantly, we wanted to serve our customers in a seamless way and be able to put in a lot of innovation through our bottling system, which had to move from huge monolithic products to a highly fragmented set of products. That original proposition has not changed. What we are seeing today is disciplined pricing in the market. And from our perspective, the integrated operating system is very valuable and we intend to continue to operate that way. So on the commodity inflation, Hugh, quickly?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Very briefly, it's almost entirely driven by foreign exchange, x foreign exchange, the commodity inflation is almost flattish.
componenttext: Yes. Very briefly, it's almost entirely driven by foreign exchange, x foreign exchange, the commodity inflation is almost flattish.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Marshall of Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Marshall of Barclays.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I actually have a high level kind of strategic question for you. Indra, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned the challenges in center of the store food recently. And I think a couple of years ago, you've labeled these businesses as not necessarily core
componenttext: I actually have a high level kind of strategic question for you. Indra, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned the challenges in center of the store food recently. And I think a couple of years ago, you've labeled these businesses as not necessarily core to the mission, even though a nice cash flow-generating asset. I'm kind of wondering how you're thinking about those businesses in the current environment, especially with everything we've seen going on with food and the interest rate environment that we're seeing now.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's 2 kinds of businesses I said were not core to the mission. Quaker is very core to the mission. What we were talking about is sort of the peripheral businesses we got as part of the Quaker Oats acquisition, the Golden Grain, the Aunt Jemima
componenttext: I think there's 2 kinds of businesses I said were not core to the mission. Quaker is very core to the mission. What we were talking about is sort of the peripheral businesses we got as part of the Quaker Oats acquisition, the Golden Grain, the Aunt Jemima. Those businesses are center of the store. They're not core to our portfolio. But today, they're doing fine. They're holding their ground, sometimes even gaining share. They're generating very valuable U.S. cash flow. And these are businesses with fantastic margins. So at this point, it's more dilutive to get rid of them than to keep them. And so what we're going to do is just manage those businesses steadily as long as they don't distract us from our core mission of growing the rest of the portfolio. And that's what we're focused on. Lastly, Bill, they also provide scale to our warehouse sales operation. So at this point, just steady management of those businesses, don't distract ourselves from the core, enjoy the U.S. cash, the good margins, and that's all we're doing.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Faucher of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Faucher of JPMorgan.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Indra, I wanted to talk about sort of your old sort of buckets that the business has had in terms of Fun-for-You, Better-for-You and Good-for-You. It seems as though we're seeing a change in the consumer dynamics, particularly in the Better-for-You bucket
componenttext: Indra, I wanted to talk about sort of your old sort of buckets that the business has had in terms of Fun-for-You, Better-for-You and Good-for-You. It seems as though we're seeing a change in the consumer dynamics, particularly in the Better-for-You bucket if you look at something like diet soft drinks, what have you. So I guess, as we look at this, what do you think has changed in terms of those buckets? And what are you doing differently to respond as the consumers maybe seem less interested in what you guys had traditionally discussed as Better-for-You?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a wonderful question, John. And I'd tell you something, we've never seen the consumer as confused as they are today. And I use the word confused in a neutral way, not a negative way. If you'd asked me a few years ago, people were moving to diet sod
componenttext: That's a wonderful question, John. And I'd tell you something, we've never seen the consumer as confused as they are today. And I use the word confused in a neutral way, not a negative way. If you'd asked me a few years ago, people were moving to diet sodas. Now they view real sugar as Good-for-You. They're willing to go to organic, non-GMO products even if it has high salt, high sugar, high fat. So I think we have a challenge these days to really think about what is definition of Good-for-You from a consumer perspective. And this is unprecedented. And the old of definition of Good-for-You is being challenged right now. So I think the best way to think about this is to think about the fruit and vegetable corridor, a protein corridor, a grains corridor, and then sort of a predominantly carb corridor. And then within that, just vary our strategy based on what the consumer is thinking about. Because especially millennials today have got very different definitions of Good-for-You versus Fun-for-You. They don't really make the definition. And the difference that way they're look much more at ingredients. So we are also going through a little change in our thinking. The good news is whatever the segmentation is, our portfolio is still balanced and we can actually flex to either definition. So we are managing the business by watching both.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Swartzberg of Stifel Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Swartzberg of Stifel Financial.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Indra or Hugh, a question about FX from a transactional standpoint. Obviously, you have some major productivity programs underway and we're a couple of years into this. But when you look at specifically the countries of Mexico and China, are these hi
componenttext: Yes. Indra or Hugh, a question about FX from a transactional standpoint. Obviously, you have some major productivity programs underway and we're a couple of years into this. But when you look at specifically the countries of Mexico and China, are these higher transactional costs that are dollar-related, are they impacting you to the scope or the phasing of some of your productivity programs in those particular countries?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Mark, I would say no. It really doesn't affect us a great deal. We obviously have got to be cognizant of what's happening with transactional ForEx to the degree that we are experiencing that in a particular market. As Indra mentioned earlier, we're
componenttext: Okay. Mark, I would say no. It really doesn't affect us a great deal. We obviously have got to be cognizant of what's happening with transactional ForEx to the degree that we are experiencing that in a particular market. As Indra mentioned earlier, we're tending to price through about 75% of it. But in terms of if transactional ForEx is affecting capital that we would put in to drive productivity, it really isn't impacting us a great deal. It's not slowing down the rate because the returns on those initiatives tend to be pretty solid and we can overcome the FX impact.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Amit Sharma of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Amit Sharma of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick clarification first. The 75% rule that you're talking about, is that just to cover underlying inflation? Or should we expect that to cover the transactional FX as well?
componenttext: Just a quick clarification first. The 75% rule that you're talking about, is that just to cover underlying inflation? Or should we expect that to cover the transactional FX as well?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, transactional FX is what drives some of the inflation, and so they're all related. And I've given you 75% as what we are doing today, it varies around that number. Sometimes we can do more, sometimes we can do less. But as a basket, it's around 75
componenttext: I mean, transactional FX is what drives some of the inflation, and so they're all related. And I've given you 75% as what we are doing today, it varies around that number. Sometimes we can do more, sometimes we can do less. But as a basket, it's around 75%. The thing, Amit, is that globally, we've been through in some countries of the world, hyperinflation inflation, extraordinary inflation, geopolitical crises, we've been through that. And across PepsiCo exists a lot of playbooks on how to manage through these sorts of issues. So when we have a problem like this in a country, we bring the experts in, we use one of these playbooks, and then we use our extraordinary teams in these countries. Then we judiciously manage through pricing, productivity, revenue management to see how best to insulate the portfolio. And I think the good news about the portfolio is that the portfolio serves as a good hedge when you have a mix of countries, mix of businesses. That's what allows us deliver the 7% constant currency growth, reiterate that guidance and the free cash flow guidance.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. To be clear on that, I would think of the 75% as a rough modeling guideline, not an internal principle as to how we execute market-by-market. We vary market-by-market based on the opportunities in front of us.
componenttext: Yes. To be clear on that, I would think of the 75% as a rough modeling guideline, not an internal principle as to how we execute market-by-market. We vary market-by-market based on the opportunities in front of us.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Steve Powers of UBS.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Steve Powers of UBS.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a couple of final clarifications. First, on pricing, specifically in Europe. Clearly, it's difficult to realize in Western Europe, but the 6% pricing this quarter is falling well short of sort of the currency headwinds. So was there additional
componenttext: Maybe just a couple of final clarifications. First, on pricing, specifically in Europe. Clearly, it's difficult to realize in Western Europe, but the 6% pricing this quarter is falling well short of sort of the currency headwinds. So was there additional pricing that maybe you took after the quarter in Eastern Europe and Russia or that you still expect to take to catch up with currency? And if so, what type of elasticity should we kind of think about around that incremental pricing? That's first. And then second maybe, Hugh, just some clarifications and sensitivities around that updated FX guidance. Understanding you use consensus rates, if we benchmark to today's spot rates, can you give us some sense of what that outlook would look like at spot rates and how it might improve? And then conversely, if you did move to the latest rates in Venezuela, some sensitivities around the magnitude of that impact in the other direction.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Steve. That's multiple questions, but let me to try to address it efficiently. Number one, you will see more pricing in Eastern Europe that will come through. To date, the elasticities in Russia have been less than 1. So as we put incremental pricin
componenttext: Okay, Steve. That's multiple questions, but let me to try to address it efficiently. Number one, you will see more pricing in Eastern Europe that will come through. To date, the elasticities in Russia have been less than 1. So as we put incremental pricing in we'll see how it looks going forward. But to date, the elasticity has been less than 1. So obviously, that's been favorable to us. Number two, in terms of the overall FX, spot numbers are moving around so much, I actually don't pay as much attention to spot as I do to market consensus. So not clear to me, it might be a little bit favorable at this point. But I would just stay focused on the guidance that we've given you rather than trying to anticipate it. It's awfully complex. And then the last question was around...

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was it.
componenttext: That was it.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that was it. Anyway, Steve, if you have another question, you can give Jamie and the team a call.
componenttext: I think that was it. Anyway, Steve, if you have another question, you can give Jamie and the team a call.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you, all, for your questions. And in closing, I just want to say that we have taken the necessary steps to position ourselves for sustainable, long-term growth. I believe we're off to a good start in 2015 and we are navigating well throughout a
componenttext: Yes. Thank you, all, for your questions. And in closing, I just want to say that we have taken the necessary steps to position ourselves for sustainable, long-term growth. I believe we're off to a good start in 2015 and we are navigating well throughout an uncertain and volatile environment. And I believe the first quarter of 2015 is a good example of how a well-constructed portfolio, appropriate investment and disciplined execution can drive strong constant currency top and bottom line results. Our first quarter results give me confidence that our plans are working and that we're on track to deliver on our financial goals in 2015. I thank you for your time this very busy morning and for the confidence you've placed in us with your investment. Have a great day.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for participating in PepsiCo's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: Thank you for participating in PepsiCo's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to PepsiCo's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and will be archived at www.pepsico.com. It is now my pleasure to introduce Mr. Jamie Caulfield, Senior Vice Presid
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to PepsiCo's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's call is being recorded and will be archived at www.pepsico.com. It is now my pleasure to introduce Mr. Jamie Caulfield, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Mr. Caulfield, you may begin.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me on the call today are Indra Nooyi, PepsiCo's Chairman and CEO; and Hugh Johnston, PepsiCo's CFO. We'll lead off the call this morning with prepared remarks and then turn to Q&A. As we begin the call, it's importan
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Joining me on the call today are Indra Nooyi, PepsiCo's Chairman and CEO; and Hugh Johnston, PepsiCo's CFO. We'll lead off the call this morning with prepared remarks and then turn to Q&A. 
As we begin the call, it's important to note the following. We will make forward-looking statements on this call. Any forward-looking statement inherently involves risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from current predictions and expectations.
Information on such risks can be found in today's earnings release and our most recent Form 10-K and subsequent SEC filings. In addition, we'll discuss results using non-GAAP measures, and you can find the GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations on our website under the Investors section in the Events and Presentations tab.
Beginning with the third quarter of 2015, PepsiCo will realign some of -- certain of its reportable segments as you saw in this morning's press release. Within the next 30 days, PepsiCo expects to provide reclassified summary segment reporting for 2013 and '14 and the first 2 quarters of 2015 to reflect the company's new structure. 
And now it's my pleasure to introduce Indra Nooyi.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jamie, and good morning, everyone. We are very pleased with our performance in the quarter. Organic revenue grew 5.1% with global snacks up 8%, and global beverages up 2%. Core gross margin improved by 115 basis points.Core constant currency
componenttext:
Thank you, Jamie, and good morning, everyone. We are very pleased with our performance in the quarter. Organic revenue grew 5.1% with global snacks up 8%, and global beverages up 2%. Core gross margin improved by 115 basis points.
Core constant currency operating profit grew 8%, and core constant currency EPS grew 11%. Based on the strength of the quarter, our overall first half results and our outlook for the remainder of the year, we are increasing our full year core constant currency 2015 EPS growth outlook to 8%.
Our businesses are performing well, both in the top line and bottom line. PepsiCo Americas Beverages had an outstanding quarter. 3% organic revenue growth translated to 10% core currency operating profit growth.
Frito-Lay North America delivered another quarter of very strong results with organic revenue up 3%, and core constant currency operating profit up 7%. And our developing and emerging markets delivered 11% organic growth in the quarter, revenue growth despite the ongoing volatility in many regions of the world.
Looking across some of our key D&E markets, our businesses continued to prove resilient. Turkey and Saudi Arabia achieved double-digit organic revenue growth; China, Egypt and the Philippines achieved high single-digit organic revenue growth; and Mexico achieved mid-single-digit organic revenue growth.
Now I assume you had a chance to  read the release this morning. So rather than go through the numbers in detail by segment or country, what we will do on this call and going forward is to give you an update and provide a bit more detail on each of our big initiatives to drive performance, namely innovation supported by brand management, flawless execution, self-sustaining productivity, prudent capital allocation and talented new management.
So today we will focus primarily on innovation and touch briefly on the others. And on future calls, we'll highlight one of each of the other initiatives. So let me begin with innovation.
Our innovation success to date is the result of significant investments in and changes to our innovation, research and development capabilities and processes that began about 8 years ago. At that time, we were an extremely decentralized organization, operating as a loose confederation of geographic business units with each largely driving its own development agenda and establishing their own processes.
Development is focused largely on product line extension, and that structure while effective in its time led to  less efficient use of resources with redundant projects often being undertaken in different parts of the world and suboptimal resource allocation to the most promising ideas.
As a result, much of our innovation lack staying power. In part, this has to do with the quality of our innovation, but it also had to do with the inability to appropriately incubate innovation in the marketplace. And to advance these opportunities, we undertook a major transformation to improve our R&D function and innovation capabilities.
Specifically, we established global category groups charged with coordinating global innovation. This resulted in a more focused innovation agenda, a greater emphasis on development platforms rather than product line extensions only and more efficient allocation of development resources as we have significantly reduced redundant efforts through better coordination.
Two, we globally adopted the proprietary demand moment framework originally developed at Frito-Lay North America. The framework focuses on the triggers of consumption by examining consumer needs based on the context of the occasion. This created a much stronger linkage between consumer and shopper insights in the R&D function and has led to renovation being more incremental to top line growth.
Three, we implemented a common discipline stage process to gain better visibility into marketing pipeline of R&D projects, to allocate resources of the more promising ideas and new platforms and to ensure better balance of refresh, reframe and breakthrough innovation.
Four, to facilitate more rapid lift and shift of our most successful innovation launches from one market to another. We provided our businesses with better visibility of new products and their performance around the globe. 
Five, we increased our investment in R&D starting in 2008. In fact, from 2011 to 2014 alone, our investment in R&D has increased almost 40%.
Next, more recently, we established a design capability start world-class design balance. Increasingly, we're involving design in early stages of innovation, taking to account the entire content consumption cycle to create truly memorable experiences for our consumers.
And lastly, we are using reverse engineering century, leveraging our learnings in emerging markets to the benefits of thinking realistically about low-cost design of new products, packaging and equipment without sacrificing quality.
We are pleased with the progress we have made across all these fronts and the tangible results we have seen. Innovation as a percent of total revenue reached 9% in 2014, an improvement of 150 basis points compared to 2 years ago.
3 PepsiCo products received the 2015 Nielsen Breakthrough Innovation Award. This award recognizes the most successful and enduring new CPG products launched in the U.S. in 2013. PepsiCo was the only company to receive multiple awards this year.
And over the past 3 years, we've introduced a number of new products that have achieved our own pace to achieve more than $100 million each in annual retail sales, including Tostitos Cantina, Mountain Dew Kickstart, Doritos, Cheetos fun mix and Gatorade Fierce Blue Cherry and Frost Laser Cherry.
More recently, we have successfully using premium innovation within key categories to capture more price realizations, to relaunch [ph] and launch DEWshine, a craft premium soda inspired by Mountain Dew brand roots in the backwoods of Tennessee.
We're also innovating on packaging, capitalizing on the success of our consumer-engaging Lay's Do Us A Flavor campaign, we launched Lay's summer days campaign, encouraging fans to create custom of Lay's potato chips, featuring photos of their favorite summer moments to share with friends and family on social media.
Adding excitement to this experience, 10,000 lucky fans will receive a real-life customized bag of Lay's classic potato chips featuring the photo they digitally submitted, offering consumers personalized packaging for the first time in the brand's history.
We're also capitalizing on consumer health and wellness demand. As consumers are embracing almond milk and other plant-based proteins as an alternative to traditional dairy milk, Naked Juice has launched 2 new nut milks, dairy almond nut milk and peachy almond nut milk.
And in Quaker Foods North America, our new quick-cook, steel-cut innovation has propelled us to the #1 market position in the on-trend and growing Steel Cut Oatmeal segment by making preparation much more convenient.
Channel-focused innovation is advancing our full service business, and we're launching new line of craft soft drinks called soda in the summer. The lineup includes unique and contemporary takes of traditional craft labels. Flavors include black cherry paragon, lemon Berry asai, vanilla cream and pineapple cream. They contain no high fructose corn syrup and are made with certified cane sugar and natural flavors.
And of course, we continue to refresh and refrain our key brands to maintain a high level of consumer engagement and excitement.
Now innovation has also contributed to good market share performance in the second quarter in the United States. And I believe our results are impressive. We held LRB value share while delivering strong net price realization. We gained value share across important subcategories, including sport drinks and ready-to-drink teas.
Gatorade share of sports drinks surpassed 80%. Mountain Dew gained 40 basis points of value share within the CSD the category in Q2. In fact, if you add Kickstart, DEWshine and Baja and together, this represents more than 2 points of CSD value share in the most recent 4-week period, placing our recent Mountain Dew innovation by itself as the fourth-largest flavored CSD behind Mountain Dew, Dr. Pepper and Sprite.
In Q2, we grew retail sales in measured channels in the U.S. for regular colas and Mountain Dew within CSDs, for Gatorade, Lipton Tea and Naked Juice within our noncarb portfolio. And Frito-Lay, we held value share in savory snacks, and in Quaker Foods, we gained value share in key categories hot and ready-to-eat cereals while expanding gross margin and stepping up advertising and marketing at the same time.
And our innovation is driving growth for our retail partners as well. In the second quarter, PepsiCo was once again the largest contributor to the U.S. retail sales growth among all food and beverage manufacturers with over $400 million of retail sales growth in all measured channels. This was more than 2x the next largest contributor to growth and represented more growth than the next 14 largest manufacturers combined. Notably, North America Beverages was the key driver of U.S. retail sales growth within PepsiCo and the largest contributor to the U.S. retail sales growth on a standalone basis.
Our intention is to continue to invest in innovation, build upon our already strong capability base and further sharpen our holistic innovation process to drive greater for customers, create compelling products for our consumers and ultimately increase the contribution of new products to our total revenue.
So that's the story on innovation. Turning now to execution. We ramped up our execution focus across the value chain from to shelf. We established clear consistent performance metrics to track and benchmark the effectiveness and efficiency of everyone of our core value-driving activities from safety to manufacturing utilization, to transport efficiency to promotional display execution.
Execution is never-ending journey as it will always be opportunity to raise the game of the below-average performers, either manufacturing lines but we're seeing solidification and steady improvement across the enterprise, and this is translating into good market performance and financial results.
Turning now to productivity and disciplined capital allocation. As you know, we have a goal of delivering $5 billion in productivity savings over 5 years from 2015 to 2019 just approximately $1 billion per year. Our current program follows a similarly aggressive 3-year, $3 billion program that we successfully concluded in 2014. And overall, our productivity initiatives are driving meaningful results.
Over the 3 years ending in 2014, despite adverse ForEx, we've realized $1 billion of annual activity savings, net revenue per employees up 10% and EBIT per employee's up 9%. And since 2012, gross margins have consistently expanded.
Similarly, our capital allocation discipline is yielding full results. From year-end 2011 to the second quarter of 2015, net CapEx as a percent of revenue has improved from 4.9% to 4.1% on a rolling 4-quarter basis. And this 80 basis points reduction equates to approximately $500 million in incremental annual free cash flow.
And since 2012 through the second quarter of 2015, core net ROIC has improved by 310 basis points to 18.4% on a rolling 4-quarter basis.
And finally, people renewal in development. This is an area that I and the Board spent a lot of time on. Our focus is twofold here: making sure we have the right leaders in place leaders in place today and that we're developing the next 2 generations of leadership for the company. And as you also know, good management does not happen in short term.
It requires taking a long-term view and very detailed analytical planning. At the core of our people renewal and management plan, we have to focus on the 200 critical leadership roles in our company. These are the roles that are most important to our success and that provide the greatest experiential development for our executives.
For each of these roles, we have developed the pipeline that ensures we have one immediate successor candidates, 2 people in 1- to 3-year time frame and then another 3 people ready 4 to 6 years out.
As a result of these process, we have deliberately developing top talent by giving them multiple category, geography and job experiences and ensuring we have well-developed succession plan. The other priority we have is ensuring we have the right balance of homegrown talent that we augment our talent pool from time-to-time with exception of executives referred from outside the company. And I believe our plans are working. And we've had executive transitions, both planned and unplanned, have been smooth and coordinated. And as you look at our current leadership, you will find that executives have a very broad critical experiences within PepsiCo over many years across functions, geographies and categories, people like Tom Greco, Al Carey, Sanjeev Chadha, Ramon Laguarta and Hugh Johnston, and folks have been brought into PepsiCo later in their careers to augment our skill base and stretch our thinking people like Mehmood Khan,  Laxman Narasimhan and Tony West.
And we are grooming our next generation of leadership by giving them critical experiences, people like Mike who runs our Russia -- I mean, I'm sorry, our China operation, and Brian Newman, whose promotions we announced last night.
So to conclude, we have are pleased with our financial performance for the first half of 2015 and the progress well with across our value driving initiatives. Clearly, there are a number of macro changes around the world, but we believe we have the right strategies and programs in place to enable us to continue to navigate successfully to the current environment.
The construction of our products and geographic portfolios enable us to continue to deliver strong results, in part because our balanced portfolio rates in natural hedge against the global macro and political volatility that has become the new normal. And all of these boosts our confidence in our ability to continue to achieve our financial targets.
So with that, let me turn it over to Hugh.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Indra. Good morning, everyone. Turning to our guidance. As Indra mentioned, based on the strength of our first half results and our outlook for the remainder of the year, we've increased full year core constant currency EPS growth target
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Indra. Good morning, everyone. Turning to our guidance. As Indra mentioned, based on the strength of our first half results and our outlook for the remainder of the year, we've increased full year core constant currency EPS growth target to 8% from 7% previously. Our other targets remain unchanged. .
For the full year 2015, we continue to expect mid-single-digit organic revenue growth, core operating margin expansion as organic top line growth and productivity should offset negative geographic mix and commodity inflation, which incorporates the impact of transaction-related foreign exchange headwinds and approximately $1 billion of productivity savings.
Below the division operating line, we continue to expect corporate costs to be lower, a core tax rate of approximately 25% and a reduced share count. We expect foreign exchange translation to negatively impact net revenue and core earnings per share growth by approximately 9 and 11 percentage points, respectively, based on current market consensus rates.
Our outlook for the year assumes translation of our Venezuela results at a SICAD rate of VEF 12.8 per U.S. dollar. Should circumstances dictate use of higher rate, this would also negatively impact our U.S. dollar results.
Taking our 2014 core EPS of $4.63 and applying our guidance and current market consensus of foreign exchange impact implies 2015 core EPS of approximately $4.49.
As you model out the third quarter, I'd ask you to consider the following: Foreign exchange translation should have an approximate 11-point unfavorable impact on the third quarter, net revenue growth an approximate 12-point unfavorable impact on third quarter core EPS growth based on current market consensus rates. And we expect a profit decline in QFNA as we lap last year's gain on the sale of the cereal business.
Below the division operating profit line, net interest expense is expected to continue to increase in the third quarter versus last year, driven by higher interest rates and net debt balances, and our tax rate in the third quarter is expected to be higher than the third quarter of 2014.
From a cash flow perspective, we continue to expect full year free cash flow of more than $7 billion. We expect our capital allocation discipline to continue to drive core ROIC improvement. This is building on the steady progress we have made in ROIC with core net ROIC up 310 basis points from 2012 to 18.4% through the second quarter of 2015 on a rolling 4-quarter basis.
And consistent with prior outlook, we expect to return between approximately $8.5 billion and $9 billion to shareholders in 2015, through both dividends and share repurchases. As a reminder, our previously announced 7% dividend per share increase commenced with the June payment. Our annualized dividend is now $2.81, an approximate 60% payout ratio based on 2014 core EPS. This represents the 43rd consecutive year of annual dividend increases, and our annualized dividends per share have grown at 10% compound annual rate over the past 10 years.
So to summarize, our core constant currency earnings per share outlook for 2015 has improved from our last call. And free cash flow, disciplined capital allocation and returning cash to our shareholders remain top priorities for the company. 
With that, operator, we'll take the first question.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of John Faucher from JPMorgan.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: 2 quick questions here. One, can you just give us a little bit of the rationale in terms of the merger of the Latin American food and beverage businesses? That just sort of the regions need to manage their regions? And then secondly, can you talk a little
componenttext: 2 quick questions here. One, can you just give us a little bit of the rationale in terms of the merger of the Latin American food and beverage businesses? That just sort of the regions need to manage their regions? And then secondly, can you talk a little bit about the Frito volume, which was a little bit light relative to trends, anything in particular going on there?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me talk a bit about the Latin American merger. We are seeing success in Europe and AMEA with all of the part of one management of those regions. We're able to get more productive -- more productivity, take out costs and, especially with the volatile e
componenttext: Let me talk a bit about the Latin American merger. We are seeing success in Europe and AMEA with all of the part of one management of those regions. We're able to get more productive -- more productivity, take out costs and, especially with the volatile economies, we have to get more and more agile and more creative about how to take out costs. And it's not just costs within our systems, John, I think even with our bottling partners, there's an opportunity to operate figure out how not to duplicate efforts between the 2 companies, and we are seeing those initiatives payoff in AMEA and Europe. And we decided now to do that in Latin America. We're in the middle of a major productivity program in Latin American Foods, and integrating Latin American beverages with food gives us that much more of a cost base to work with. Lastly, given the volatility of these economies there, I think it's very important to be very become a lean mean machine there in order to and reinvest to grow the top line. So that's Latin America. Second is on the Frito volume, again, we watched the Frito performance very carefully as Tom Greco and the Frito team. In our potato chip business, we were going through a revenue management program, and that revenue management program is actually yielding good revenue growth and improving top line growth and profitability for our retailers. And one of the results of the revenue management program is that it is going to impact volume because the price that architecture shifts some of the volume to certain excesses, which impacts volume in the short term but over the long term, it's the right thing for the business. So I'd rather play up to balance of the year then look at our results in 2016.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, happy to do that, Brian. As you all know we have provided read the extensive disclosures in our 10-Qs and 10-K on the question. In the Q that we intend to file after today market's close, and consistent with past Qs, you will see Venezuela represents
componenttext: Yes, happy to do that, Brian. As you all know we have provided read the extensive disclosures in our 10-Qs and 10-K on the question. In the Q that we intend to file after today market's close, and consistent with past Qs, you will see Venezuela represents approximately 2% of our revenue and operating profit. We also have met monetary assets of approximately $335 million and nonmonetary assets of approximately $725 million. Now if we were to take all of that and go to, Venezuela would then represent 0% or very slightly above 0% of our revenue and operating profits. So it's roughly a 2% hit on both revenue and operating profit. We have a charge of approximately $325 million related to the net monetary assets. It also likely lead to an impairment of our nonmonetary assets. The one thing for investors to consider on this is from an economic standpoint is really would not represent a big impact on ethical given that been as well as largely a self-sufficient, self-funding operation. We're not putting any capital to speak of in the country and we've not been able to redeploy any of our Venezuelan cash outside of Venezuela. So from the perspective of cash flow and cash management, it would not have a meaningful impact on cash returns.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that 2% effect on operating income though it will be above and beyond the guidance that you've given this morning in terms of the 11% currency hit to EPS for the year. Is that right?
componenttext: So that 2% effect on operating income though it will be above and beyond the guidance that you've given this morning in terms of the 11% currency hit to EPS for the year. Is that right?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct. Right now, we're assuming for that as of the year for Venezuela is VEF 12.8 because that was the recent SICAD option, which is a pretty robust option, but if we did the make the move to SIMADI, the impact would be that much more significan
componenttext: That's correct. Right now, we're assuming for that as of the year for Venezuela is VEF 12.8 because that was the recent SICAD option, which is a pretty robust option, but if we did the make the move to SIMADI, the impact would be that much more significant.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question, I guess, thinking about the back half the year, it seems like in the first half has come in better than expected and with organic sales at mid single-digit, it seems like it's been a little bit better operating leve
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question, I guess, thinking about the back half the year, it seems like in the first half has come in better than expected and with organic sales at mid single-digit, it seems like it's been a little bit better operating leverage the currency neutral operating profit has been better. So in the second half, why just in terms higher-level thoughts but in terms of why that is on continuing the second half? Is there something you are seeing on the commodity costs front? Is it there the flow of safe productivity savings? Just something that sort of raise that flag for the back half the year that you want to continue to kind of see this in the current growth.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's 3 things I'd remind you in that regard, Bryan. Number one, the back half last particularly Q4, but both Q3 and Q4 are more challenging than the first half overlap. So we're certainly facing more of an uphill growth in the back half of
componenttext: Yes, I think there's 3 things I'd remind you in that regard, Bryan. Number one, the back half last particularly Q4, but both Q3 and Q4 are more challenging than the first half overlap. So we're certainly facing more of an uphill growth in the back half of the year. Number two, you're correct. Commodities are more headwind in the back half the year than they were in the first half of the year. And number three, again, recall certainly some of what we're seeing in the news these days, the world remains a very volatile place. We have big businesses in the Middle East. We have big businesses in Russia. And as we model things out, we obviously try to ensure that we give investors appropriate guidance that we think incorporating some of that ability volatility. So we're not assuming the perfect sunny day going forward as well. So that goes into our thinking as you look at the so-called target zone between the first half and the second half the year.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. The first one is, is there a price war going on in snacks, especially in the U.K? Because of some of the market share chance trends it seems like categories in a lot of pressure and gringos and are getting aggressive. I know it's not
componenttext: Couple of questions. The first one is, is there a price war going on in snacks, especially in the U.K? Because of some of the market share chance trends it seems like categories in a lot of pressure and gringos and are getting aggressive. I know it's not a huge business, but I just wondered how far up that travels across Europe and what the competitive response has been? And I have a follow-up.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't call it the price war. I just think the retail environment in the U.K. remains interesting. As the high street retailers are going to the onset of challenges is you got the entry of the discounters, all of that is causing the entire competitive
componenttext: I wouldn't call it the price war. I just think the retail environment in the U.K. remains interesting. As the high street retailers are going to the onset of challenges is you got the entry of the discounters, all of that is causing the entire competitive situation, the U.K. to be reset. And being one of the major food and beverage companies in the U.K. and the largest salty-snack company in the U.K., I think we have to be careful how we make our transitions with the high-street retailers and the discounters. And so on the short term, we did lose some share. But we have plans in place to recovery that share and somehow navigate through these retail environment changes. Again, Bill, I'd tell you, around the world, as we see major changes in the retail environment, always the short term, there will be some dislocations because we have some we have to make the changes in the business model very, very carefully.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 2 quick ones for you, Indra. First, with respect to North American carbonated soft drinks and broadly in the industry, given more recent pricing discipline, which is taken hold. My question is given this dynamic, how material these did this change your
componenttext: So 2 quick ones for you, Indra. First, with respect to North American carbonated soft drinks and broadly in the industry, given more recent pricing discipline, which is taken hold. My question is given this dynamic, how material these did this change your view North American carbonated soft drink profit goal. And did you see mid-single-digit growth as sort of more sustainable you're looking out not just this year but longer term? And then sort of a follow-up, sticking with North America Beverages, can you give us an update into your own Diet Pepsi the change to the formulation there, your competitors are not following and how you're thinking about that? How are you defining success there with that product?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of the North American pricing, look, we've been talking about disciplined pricing for a long time. I'd say a couple of years. I'm glad that there is disciplined pricing in the marketplace right now, and there's also innovation in the market that.
componenttext: In terms of the North American pricing, look, we've been talking about disciplined pricing for a long time. I'd say a couple of years. I'm glad that there is disciplined pricing in the marketplace right now, and there's also innovation in the market that. And look, we will keep playing our game. We will focus on disciplined pricing, good revenue management, puts innovation on to the marketplace. And ultimately, it depends on the competitive situation, what the profit holds is the business all the North American business in totality. But we believe this is the right way to participate and play in this very, very important large segment. In terms of the Diet Pepsi, big business. And I think for some reason, which we can't really explain, as the favor some consumers. And from our perspective, we just want to make sure we have an offering for all of the consumers who want to switch out of aspartame, and we formulated a very, very good product, which is aspartame free will be available in the markets starting in late August. So for all of those consumers who are looking for an alternative to an aspartame sweetened byproduct, we will have a product. And for those consumers who still love Diet Pepsi with aspartame, we'll figure out how to make it available online. So I think this is a consumer tree then strategy to offer all of the diet lovers, a diet cola that's aspartame free.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say that innovation is allowing us to get a lot more price/mix. Price realization particular something is very, very important in today's environment. And it's product packaging, process innovation, but we're also spending a lot of time on revenue man
componenttext: I'd say that innovation is allowing us to get a lot more price/mix. Price realization particular something is very, very important in today's environment. And it's product packaging, process innovation, but we're also spending a lot of time on revenue management. I mean, really thinking through portion sizes, pack sizes, pack sizes. And I think these combination of interesting products coming into the marketplace and interesting packages and interesting combinations of packages is worth resulting in incrementality on the revenue side and actually resulted in higher profit flow-through. And we're seeing it across carbonated soft drinks,, I mean, whether it's a DEWshine or BAJA BLAST or any of those products you can we're seeing it even in Europe and Russia and Latin America and AMEA aware I'd say creative revenue management tactics, coupled with innovation that cuts through the clutter, is resulting in flow-through to the bottom line. Again, I think in these environments, the focus should be on revenue and profit, not necessarily on volume growth. We focus more on unit growth, revenue and profit in these environments because a chase for volume results in the whole business hurricane. So I think with revenue management, unit growth, value growth and profit is what we focus on. And that's what our innovation efforts are yielding to date, the almost 10% I think the high 9s, our innovation performances, something that is a significant step-up. And we keep watching that metric very, very carefully.

componenttextpreview: A question on there's actually talk of our Russia putting an advertising ban I guess on sugar drinks and fatty foods and things like that. And in the context of that come I'm just wondering if you see increased regulatory risks to your food or beverage bu
componenttext: A question on there's actually talk of our Russia putting an advertising ban I guess on sugar drinks and fatty foods and things like that. And in the context of that come I'm just wondering if you see increased regulatory risks to your food or beverage business around the globe and what you think the impact might be, for example, in Russia and how you would handle that?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Caroline, we were among the first  people to recognize this, and we've been retooling our portfolio to make sure that first of all we have a diverse portfolio that can weather any sort of action or any part of our portfolio. But we're also in constructive
componenttext: Caroline, we were among the first  people to recognize this, and we've been retooling our portfolio to make sure that first of all we have a diverse portfolio that can weather any sort of action or any part of our portfolio. But we're also in constructive conversations with governments to make sure that there aren't any discriminatory taxes or discriminatory action on any of our categories. Having said that, in Russia in particular, it is perhaps the most diverse portfolio of any part of our company between dairy and juices and snacks ranging from Fun-for-You to Good-for-You and beverages to CSDs actually a small portion of our business in Russia. And so if you want to use an example of the most diverse portfolio of Fun-for-You, Better-for-You and Good-for-You skewing towards Good-for-You, I think it's our Russia portfolio. So we feel good about Russia so far. And we always want any geopolitical issues to deal with from the Russian perspective, but our business is doing well, and the economy has been good to us, and the Russian business environment has been good for us. So we like it.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Swartzberg of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Swartzberg of Stifel.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about procurement, specifically, in that larger $5 billion productivity aim. Can you give us a bit of an update on to what extent that number is included in the $5 billion, and how you're leveraging your
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about procurement, specifically, in that larger $5 billion productivity aim. Can you give us a bit of an update on to what extent that number is included in the $5 billion, and how you're leveraging your global scale? And whether if at all these changes in the reporting structure and particularly Latin America have any influence on how you go after procurement savings as a global entity?

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hugh, go ahead.
componenttext: Hugh, go ahead.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm happy to take that one, Mark. The answer to your question is quite straightforward. We don't include procurement savings as part of productivity. Productivity is focused on the operating cost structure, not on the commodity and procurement cost s
componenttext: Yes, I'm happy to take that one, Mark. The answer to your question is quite straightforward. We don't include procurement savings as part of productivity. Productivity is focused on the operating cost structure, not on the commodity and procurement cost structure. The way we report procurement savings is we share with you on a net commodity inflation number. So that includes gross commodity inflation, less whatever we can do in terms of managing what we call value engineering. So managing our commodities two a lower cost through more efficient packaging, trading different types of juices and things like that. So the $5 billion number does not include any savings from procurement at all. That's all captured in net commodity inflation.

headline: Pepsico, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 09, 2015
